Today’s essential reads

How to Become a Master at Talking to Strangers

Entrepreneur · 19 min

Psychologists have found that just making small talk with a stranger can be cognitively demanding, tiring, and even stressful.

How to Tell Whether You're Stressed or Depressed

Fascinating stories

You’re a Bad Listener: Here’s How to Remember What People Say

Fast Company · 3 min

We come into conversations with our own agendas and low attention spans, but if you want to build better relationships you need to master active listening.

Why do we buy what we buy?

Vox · 14 min

A sociologist on why people buy too many things.

It’s too late for Black Widow

The Verge · 5 min

Marvel’s latest film thoroughly skewers the franchise’s portrayal of Black Widow... far too late.

The toppling of Saddam’s statue: how the US military made a myth

The Guardian · 20 min

In 2003, the destruction of one particular statue in Baghdad made worldwide headlines and came to be a symbol of western victory in Iraq. But there was so much more to it – or rather, so much less.

Two Tips That Instantly Improve Your Everyday Writing Forever

Darius Foroux · 4 min

If you think about it, you accomplish most daily tasks with writing.

The Kids Are Alright

Why now is the time to rethink COVID safety protocols for children — and everyone else.

6 U.S. Islands Where You Can’t Help but Slow Down

Afar · 3 min

Whether you’re strolling the coast of an Atlantic island or savoring the sunset on Hawaii’s low-key paradise, you’ll be surprised at how quickly time becomes irrelevant.

What’s the Best Jarred Salsa for Your Next Party? We Tasted and Ranked 14 Top Brands.

You can find a good salsa at the grocery store if you know what to look for.

There Are Three Sides to Every Argument

TED Ideas · 10 min

We can all play a role in helping defuse even the most bitter conflicts. Veteran negotiator William Ury shares his hard-won insights.

The Brontosaurus Is Back

Scientific American · 3 min

Decades after scientists decided that the famed dinosaur never actually existed, research says the opposite.

entry.title: The Oldest Game (Pocket Explore)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Business

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

The Oldest Game

Foreign Policy · 4 min

The very long history of industrial espionage.

What The Rise And Fall Of Lumber Prices Tell Us About The Pandemic Economy

NPR · 4 min

How One McDonald’s Employee Took Down a $24M Scam

Elle · 5 min

The Rise and Fall of the Ultimate Doomsday Prepper

The Intercept · 53 min

Why Does Everything Look the Same?

Scientific American · 5 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Economics needs to evolve

The Economist · 4 min

NOT FOR the first time this century, the global economy is rebounding from crisis. The new normal will differ from the old one. The pandemic shifted resources around, destroyed firms, and subtly adjusted habits. The economy has evolved, in other words.

The thriving business of ‘Ikea hacking’

thehustle.co · 8 min

A growing number of companies are offering design tweaks for old Ikea furniture — and business is booming.

4 Classic Business Books Recommended by Jeff Bezos, Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg

Entrepreneur · 4 min

Books can save us from years of trial and error and monumental mistakes. A book contains experiments. Decades of learning. It allows us to discover in 100 or 200 pages all the author's thoughts and experiences. For only ten dollars! It's magic, isn't it?

World’s Bubbliest Housing Markets Flash 2008 Style Warnings

Bloomberg · 2 min

Real estate prices around the world are flashing the kind of bubble warnings that haven’t been seen since the run up to the 2008 financial crisis, according to Bloomberg Economics.

How Much Energy Does Bitcoin Actually Consume?

Harvard Business Review · 9 min

Today, Bitcoin consumes as much energy as a small country. This certainly sounds alarming — but the reality is a little more complicated.

  • Coronavirus
  • Business

How 'Chaos' In the Shipping Industry Is Choking The Economy

NPR · 7 min

It's making it more difficult for stores to restock their shelves, manufacturers, carmakers and builders to get the parts they need, and farmers to export their products.

What Substack Is Really Doing to the Media

Slate · 9 min

This week, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg granted a rare, live, hourlong interview to a tech journalist, where he revealed the company’s plans for a slew of new audio products. Normally, such a scoopy, wide-ranging interview would be a coup for the media company that landed it.

Inside Pictet, the Secretive Swiss Bank for the World’s Richest People

Bloomberg · 11 min

A 215-year-old firm rooted firmly in the past finds tension adapting to the modern world.

5 Myths About Flexible Work

Harvard Business Review · 6 min

We have literally heard this statement hundreds of times over the years. It doesn’t matter what industry we’re talking about — whether it’s tech, government, finance, healthcare, or small business, we’ve heard it.

Markets Work, but Untangling Global Supply Chains Takes Time

The New York Times · 6 min

Decisions made early in the pandemic are having lasting effects on the ability of industries to fulfill surging demand. The cure for high prices is high prices.

The secretary who turned Liquid Paper into a multimillion-dollar business

thehustle.co · 6 min

Bette Nesmith Graham invented one of the most popular office supplies of the 20th century. Today, she’s largely been forgotten.

The World Economy Is Suddenly Running Low on Everything

Bloomberg · 11 min

‘It is anything but efficient or normal.’ Surging corporate demand is upending global supply chains.

The global chip shortage is starting to have major real-world consequences

CNBC · 7 min

As technology has advanced, semiconductor chips have spread from computers and cars to toothbrushes and tumble dryers — they now lurk beneath the hood of a surprising number of products.

The Mystery of the $113 Million Deli

The New York Times · 21 min

It made headlines around the world: a New Jersey sandwich shop with a soaring stock price. Was it just speculation, or something stranger?

Amsterdam Is Embracing a Radical New Economic Theory to Help Save the Environment. Could It Also Replace Capitalism?

Time · 12 min

The so-called true-price initiative, operating in the store since late 2020, is one of dozens of schemes that Amsterdammers have introduced in recent months as they reassess the impact of the existing economic system.

The Electric-Car Lesson That China Is Serving Up for America

The Atlantic · 10 min

Beijing’s push to build an entire industry from scratch helps inform how the White House should proceed.

What Happened When a 3,000-Person Village in El Salvador Became “Bitcoin Beach”

Slate · 5 min

El Salvador’s legislature has voted to become the first country in the world to adopt Bitcoin as legal tender.

The economics of movie product placements

thehustle.co · 9 min

Today’s films are brimming with products from big-name brands. How exactly do these partnerships work?

The autonomous vehicle world is shrinking — it’s overdue

The Verge · 6 min

‘The AV industry has promised too much for too long, and has delivered too little.’

How the World Ran Out of Everything

The New York Times · 9 min

Global shortages of many goods reflect the disruption of the pandemic combined with decades of companies limiting their inventories.

entry.title: What to Read When You Grew Up with the Baby-Sitters Club (Pocket Explore)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Entertainment

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

What to Read When You Grew Up with the Baby-Sitters Club

therumpus.net · 7 min

There’s something special about the Baby-Sitters Club—something that compels those of us who grew up with it (or who are just discovering it today) to fully geek out when we find each other.

The Investigative Reporting Behind America’s Obsession With Britney Spears’ Conservatorship

ProPublica · 9 min

How Loki built a different reality with retro hardware

The Verge · 6 min

Jason Sudeikis Is Having One Hell of a Year

GQ · 23 min

The story behind the iconic Vietnam episode of 'Hey Arnold!'

NBC News · 7 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

‘I was addicted to the high’: I became an influencer as a joke – then it nearly broke me

The Guardian · 16 min

Comedian Bella Younger thought wellness Instagrammers were ripe for parody. Soon she was drawn in herself. Could Deliciously Stella find her way back to reality?

Kate Winslet Has No Filter

The New York Times · 15 min

The star of ‘Mare of Easttown’ is back on the sides of buses. Without airbrushing.

How TikTok Chooses Which Songs Go Viral

Bloomberg · 7 min

The app’s hits seem to emerge organically, but the success of artists like Megan Thee Stallion reveals a highly managed curation process.

The Music Industry Is Finally Scaring Spotify

Slate · 17 min

The music business is booming again, thanks to streaming—and musicians are fighting for a bigger, better piece of the pie.

Is rewatching old TV good for the soul?

BBC · 11 min

With the amount of new shows to choose from reaching overwhelming levels, increasingly audiences are choosing to rewatch their favourite series instead. David Renshaw explores why.

  • Coronavirus

‘Summer of Soul’ Review: In 1969 Harlem, a Music Festival Stuns

The New York Times · 7 min

Stevie Wonder, Mahalia Jackson, Mavis Staples and others shine in a documentary about the Harlem Cultural Festival from Questlove. There’s no shortage of system shocks in “Summer of Soul.

Pocket’s 10 Most-Saved Stories in June 2021

Pocket · 2 min

What COVID did to friendship, the health benefits of coffee, and more.

How SoundScan Changed Everything We Knew About Popular Music

The Ringer · 18 min

Thirty years ago, Billboard changed the way it tabulated its charts, turning the industry on its head and making room for genres once considered afterthoughts to explode in the national consciousness Elton John twice. Stevie Wonder. Bruce Springsteen. Michael Jackson. Whitney Houston. That’s it.

Why it’s nearly impossible to buy an original Bob Ross painting

thehustle.co · 8 min

The famed TV artist was one of history’s most prolific painters. But you’re not likely to find his work on the open market.

TikTok and the Vibes Revival

The New Yorker · 10 min

Increasingly, what we’re after on social media is not narrative or personality but moments of audiovisual eloquence.

Why Don’t Some TV Shows Sound the Way They Used To?

The New York Times · 7 min

Licensing issues have gutted the soundtracks of many beloved series on streaming services, resulting in bewildering music cues and missing theme songs.

Screams, slashers and Thatcher: why horror films are going back to the 80s

The Guardian · 3 min

From Netflix’s Fear Street to UK shocker Censor, a new wave of gory tales are being set in the recent past – but what can they tell us about the present?

The Redemption of Justin Bieber

GQ · 25 min

He made every mistake a child star can make, including the ones that nearly destroyed him. Now—fortified by God, marriage, and a new album, Justice—Justin Bieber is putting his life back together, one positive, deliberate step at a time.

The Best Movie Performances of the Century So Far

The New Yorker · 20 min

The best cinematic performances don’t share some standard of craft or technique; what they have in common is a feeling of invention and discovery, of emotional depth and power, and a sense of self-consciousness regarding the idea and the art of performance itself.

The Pulp and Pleasure of ‘Raiders of the Lost Ark,’ 40 Years Later

The Ringer · 11 min

Watching the action-adventure classic today is like going on a treasure hunt for traces of the film’s original influences—the dime store novels and pulp fiction stories—that are largely lost on the generation that grew up with it.

A real turn-off: are celebrities ruining podcasting?

The Guardian · 8 min

From Obama and Springsteen to Paris Hilton and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, famous folk can’t stop hogging the mic.

Introducing Bistro Vibes, the Throwback Lifestyle for the Happily Washed

GQ · 8 min

Vintage Porsches, smoked salmon pizza, double-breasted blazers: your parents' cheesy signifiers are back, and they've never felt cooler.

John Swartzwelder, Sage of “The Simpsons”

The New Yorker · 32 min

The first major interview with one of the most revered comedy writers of all time.

The greatest achievements in Dumb Internet Video

Polygon · 9 min

As you can imagine, there was an impossible number of possibilities to choose from.

The Beatles: Get Back—An Exclusive Deep Dive Into Peter Jackson’s Revelatory New Movie

Vanity Fair · 17 min

This fall Disney+ unveils the three-part documentary, which mines long-lost footage for a portrait of the band’s final chapter that’s so unexpected it surprised even Paul McCartney.

entry.title: What Happened to Peanut Butter and Jelly? (Pocket Explore Food)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Food

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

What Happened to Peanut Butter and Jelly?

daily.jstor.org · 3 min

There was a time when peanut butter and jelly, spread generously on two simple slices of bread, was a quintessential American meal. But sometimes a great rise can also mean a great fall. And the mighty PB&J has fallen.

Ranch Isn’t a Dressing. It’s a Lifestyle.

tastecooking.com · 4 min

What’s the Best Jarred Salsa for Your Next Party? We Tasted and Ranked 14 Top Brands.

The Washington Post · 5 min

How to Store Berries So They Stay Fresher Longer

Bon Appétit · 3 min

Sandwiches to pack for a picnic this summer

Los Angeles Times · 3 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Chefs share their best tricks for making 16 foods everyone should know how to cook

insider.com · 6 min

Whether it's the skill of baking a basic birthday cake or properly blanching vegetables, there are certain foods that all adults should know how to make. But unfortunately, this isn't always the case, and many have gaps in their cooking knowledge.

You’ve Been Cooking Scrambled Eggs Wrong This Whole Time

Bustle · 3 min

This simple hack promises to level up brunch.

The Absolute Best Way to Cook a Hot Dog, According to So Many Tests

Food52 · 6 min

Spiral-cut? Boiled in beer? Microwaved?

Foolproof Pan Pizza Recipe

Serious Eats · 4 min

Here's how to make the sort of thick-crusted, fried-on-the-bottom, puffy, cheesy, focaccia-esque style you might remember having as a Pizza Hut personal pan pizza when you were a kid.

Ready to get cooking? Keep reading to see six one-pot pasta recipes loaded with fiber.

Well+Good · 7 min

One easy way to majorly up the fiber in your pasta dinner is to add lentils to the pot. They can cook together and it helps vary the texture, too.

A New Dawn for Grandma Cooking

tastecooking.com · 6 min

“You don’t want me in your book,” an English grandma warned Anastasia Miari and Iska Lupton, authors of Grand Dishes: Recipes and Stories from Grandmothers of the World.

Toast haste! 20 chefs on the best hot sandwiches to make in a hurry

The Guardian · 9 min

There’s a good chance that you’re still working from home. And, if that’s the case, there’s a good chance that you’ve run out of new lunches. Making cheese on toast for yourself might have seemed exotic and new last March, but now you’re sick of the stuff. And omelettes.

Sous Vide Steak Guide | The Food Lab

Serious Eats · 21 min

Steak is one of the most popular foods for first-time sous vide enthusiasts to cook, and with good reason.

The Science Behind Grilling the Perfect Steak

Smithsonian Magazine · 6 min

Want to learn how cooking transforms beef’s flavor? Meat scientists have the answers. Summer has arrived, and it’s time to fire up the backyard grill.

A Food Critic Reviews the Swedish Chef’s New Restaurant

The New Yorker · 3 min

When I heard that the Swedish Chef from “The Muppet Show” was opening a Chelsea location of his celebrated bistro, Dorg Schnorfblorp Horganblorps, I was skeptical. I’m always hesitant to believe the hype surrounding celebrity chefs, especially when they’re made of felt.

Yotam Ottolenghi’s 15-minute lunches – recipes

The Guardian · 3 min

Two 15-minute meals that are perfect for WFH lunches: a quick-cook pasta with a zippy fusion sauce, and an all-day brunch of buttery asparagus and eggs on toast.

The Baking Steel Griddle Turns Your Crappy Stove Into a Diner-Style Flattop 

Bon Appétit · 3 min

One of my first kitchen jobs was working as a line cook in a local diner in my hometown of Bucksport, Maine. My favorite days were when I was in charge of the “grill”—actually a big steel flattop—that was the heart of the kitchen.

The Best Way to Cook Vegetables: Low and Slow

The New York Times · 4 min

Crisp vegetables are often prized, but long-cooking them into tenderness can bring out their deepest flavors. Every now and then, I’ll start to tell a story before I realize it isn’t mine. Never mind that it feels like a memory of my own; it isn’t.

zucchini butter spaghetti

smitten kitchen · 4 min

I am a little bit obsessed with this spaghetti. If we’ve spoken recently, I didn’t let you not asking me about it keep me from going on about its simple summer dinner bliss.

Cookies, scones and lime tart: Yotam Ottolenghi’s recipes for gluten-free bakes

The Guardian · 7 min

Baking generally feels like alchemy: the magic that happens when eggs, sugar, butter and flour are bound together and heat is applied. So, if anything, gluten-free baking feels even more magical.

How to Grill Just About Any Vegetable

The New York Times · 9 min

Two grilling methods are all you need to cook summer’s bounty, from broccoli to asparagus, cauliflower to tomatoes. Even leafy greens benefit from a brief turn on the grill. The summer grilling season is upon us, and so are the vegetables.

Sizzling science: How to grill a flavorful steak

Ars Technica · 6 min

Summer has arrived, and it’s time to fire up the backyard grill. Though many of us are trying to eat less beef for environmental reasons, it’s hard to resist indulging in an occasional steak—and you’ll want to make the most of the experience.

From baked baby aubergines to sweet-sour peppers: Yotam Ottolenghi’s recipes for summer vegetables

The Guardian · 5 min

It’s the time of the year when I tend to eat vegetables three times a day.

Watermelon and Snap Pea Salad

Bon Appétit · 5 min

This was a hit at the 4th of July block party.

The Most Exciting Place to Eat in Los Angeles Is Chinatown

The New York Times · 8 min

LOS ANGELES — The zong are treasures, wrapped in bamboo leaves and tucked in the fridge at Pearl River Deli.

entry.title: Emergency Medicine’s Original Sin (Pocket Explore Health)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Health & Fitness

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

Emergency Medicine’s Original Sin

The Atlantic · 6 min

The misperception that paramedics are merely ambulance drivers is everyone’s problem.

How to Turn Off Harmful Stress Like a Switch

Nir Eyal · 10 min

How to Tell Whether You're Stressed or Depressed

Lifehacker · 3 min

Unlocking the ‘gut microbiome’ – and its massive significance to our health

The Guardian · 13 min

Do We Really Need to Take 10,000 Steps a Day for Our Health?

The New York Times · 3 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

It's hard to lose weight. A doctor shares 6 essential tips to make it easier

Today Show · 3 min

Processed foods often have the nutrients and fiber stripped out of them. They are more likely to be absorbed into the bloodstream quickly, which leads to an insulin surge. That’s what makes you feel hungry and can lead to overeating and weight gain.

I Gave Up Intermittent Fasting For Calorie Density and Finally Lost Weight

POPSUGAR · 4 min

Before the pandemic started in March 2020, I was doing CrossFit four to five days a week and doing extreme forms of intermittent fasting to lose the last five pounds my body had been holding on to since my son was born eight years earlier.

A Full-Body Workout for Beginners That Hits All Your Major Muscles

SELF · 3 min

If you’re just getting started exercising, a full-body workout for beginners that keeps it simple might just be a solid way into an exercise program.

Exercising Your ‘Neck Flexors’ Is The Little-Known Secret for Reducing Neck Pain

Well+Good · 4 min

If you want a quick way to check in on your posture, imagine a line running from the tip of your nose down to your chest. If it’s straight, congratulations—you’re in alignment.

Mediterranean diet may prevent memory loss and dementia, study finds

CNN · 5 min

Not sure what to eat? Why not choose foods that are good for your brain?

  • Coronavirus

This 30-Day Arm Workout Challenge Will Transform Your Upper Body

Refinery29 · 2 min

Here's the calendar in full! Download a PDF version here.

What Happens to Our Brains When We Get Depressed?

The Walrus · 28 min

The human brain, in all its complexity, is nearly impossible to model. One neuroscientist is trying anyway.

A Full-Body Strength Workout That Has Just 5 Moves

SELF · 4 min

Rest plays a huge role here.

A fatty heart puts your health at risk, regardless of your weight. Here's how to avoid it

CNN · 5 min

Lisa Drayer is a nutritionist, an author and a CNN health and nutrition contributor. While people may assume only those who are overweight have to worry about the impact of a fatty heart, the reality is that thin people can also have this sometimes life-threatening condition.

What Dermatologists Want You to Know About "Natural" Skin Care

allure.com · 4 min

There's no regulation on the word "natural," but this is what it means to these experts.

The Cosmetic Surgery “Zoom Boom” Is Real — But There’s More To The Story

Refinery29 · 13 min

When elective procedures were eventually greenlit last spring, dermatologists and plastic surgeons were met with an overwhelming demand for their services.

By Now, Burnout Is a Given

The Atlantic · 5 min

The pandemic has stripped our emotional reserves even further, laying bare our unique physical, social, and emotional vulnerabilities.

Selfies, Surgeries And Self-Loathing: Inside The Facetune Epidemic

huffpost.com · 31 min

The massively popular photo-editing app Facetune is driving a generation of young women to extreme and obsessive lengths to look flawless online.

‘Don’t freak out!’ Why keeping calm and carrying on exercising can help back pain

The Guardian · 8 min

Turns out pandemics can be atrocious for our backs.

He Inherited A Devastating Disease. A CRISPR Gene-Editing Breakthrough Stopped It

NPR · 4 min

Patrick Doherty had always been very active. He trekked the Himalayas and hiked trails in Spain. But about a year and a half ago, he noticed pins and needles in his fingers and toes. His feet got cold.

‘I’m a Cardiologist, and These Are the 5 Best Strength-Training Moves For Boosting Your Heart Health’

Well+Good · 3 min

There are certain types of workouts, like running and spinning, that we know are good for our hearts. They are, after all, literally called “cardiovascular exercises.” But if you want to keep that blood pumping at peak capacity, those daily three-mile jogs can’t do the job on all on their own.

11 Yoga With Adriene Workouts That Help Ease Back Pain

Bustle · 4 min

If you find yourself twisting and turning in an effort to alleviate a twinge-y cramp in your back, why not plop onto the floor instead and try a yoga workout for back pain? After 20 minutes of cat-ing and cow-ing, stretching and breathing, you very well might be cured — or at the very least tempor

New weight-loss tool prevents mouth from opening more than 2mm

The Guardian · 2 min

A weight-loss tool that uses magnets to stop people from opening their mouths wide enough to eat solid food has been developed by scientists in order to tackle obesity.

Stuck In A Rut? Sometimes Joy Takes A Little Practice

NPR · 13 min

Although some people are starting to test the waters of public life again, planning vacations and socializing more, others may still have lingering signs of what psychologists call languishing.

Your Body Survived a Pandemic. Don’t Punish It With Diet Fads.

The New York Times · 2 min

Don’t let the weight-loss industry shame you into thinking “back to normal” means a return to calorie counting and appetite suppressant lollipops. Ms. Schlossberg is a producer and animator with Times Opinion. Ms. Crouse is an Opinion writer and producer.

entry.title: Still, Life (Pocket Explore Parenting)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Parenting

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

Still, Life

bittersoutherner.com · 12 min

Last year, as they anticipated the birth of their first child, Gray Chapman worked her garden and wrote in her journal while her husband, Dane Sponberg, filmed the mundane and monumental days of a 2020 pregnancy.

The Hockey Sister

The New Yorker · 16 min

My Kids Navigated Our Road Trip—It Was an Adventure

Outside Magazine · 5 min

When a Bough Breaks

Aeon · 15 min

Who Wins in the Name Game?

The Atlantic · 5 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Ask Amy: I didn’t know what my wife was doing until my kids told me

The Mercury News · 4 min

Dear Amy: My wife and I have been married for 21 years, and my in-laws have never treated me particularly nicely, much less as a member of the family. My wife dreads seeing them, but fears angering her mother; I have tried to stay out of the way.

A psychologist says parents of 'exceptionally resilient and successful' kids always do these 7 things: 'Yes, some are a little intense'

CNBC · 5 min

Humans are not all equal in every way. There are a few individuals who have achieved an unparalleled mastery in their field — and they are what I call the exceptionals. Put another way, they are the 1% of the 1% of the world's most successful people.

Science Says the Most Successful Kids Have Parents Who Refuse to Embrace This Common Parenting Approach

Inc. Magazine · 4 min

In sports, early specialization appears to matter. Tiger Woods was less than 2 years old when his father began teaching him to play golf. He was on television by age 3. By the age of 5, he was in Golf Digest. Later, he became the youngest U.S. Junior Amateur champion. The youngest Masters champion.

6 Psychologically Damaging Things Parents Say To Their Kids Without Realizing It

huffpost.com · 6 min

Erase these common phrases from your parenting vocabulary.

My Aging Parents Need Parenting

Slate · 4 min

Slate Plus members get more Care and Feeding from Jamilah Lemieux every week. I know this is usually a column for parents, but today I have a question about parents. I’m in my 30s and live about a three-hour drive from my 60-year-old parents—we once used to live in the same town.

Is your kid gifted? Here are the signs, says performance expert—and how parents can raise exceptionally smart kids

CNBC · 4 min

During a child's early years, parents often look for signs that demonstrate outstanding levels of aptitude or competence in an activity, field or topic. Maybe their kid runs faster than others, or solves advanced math problems with ease, or has a keen sense of music and can sing on key.

Want to Raise Successful Kids? Jeff Bezos Says Practice This Simple Habit. (Science Backs It Up)

Inc. Magazine · 3 min

If you've been trained to do the opposite, you're not alone.

Why parents should stop blaming themselves for how their kids turn out

TED · 7 min

Trying to predict how a child will turn out based on choices made by their parents is like trying to predict a hurricane from the flap of a butterfly’s wings.

My Daughter Has a Horribly Unhealthy Relationship With Food

Slate · 8 min

Care and Feeding is Slate’s parenting advice column. Have a question for Care and Feeding? Submit it here or post it in the Slate Parenting Facebook group. I have a concern that is very delicate, and I don’t know how to address it with my daughter—or if I should address it.

Want to raise kids with high self-esteem? A parenting expert on the power of teaching your kids 'repetition and ritual'

CNBC · 3 min

The first few years of parenthood is a huge adjustment, especially if you're a working parent. All of a sudden, your baby is walking ... and talking. Then they turn three, and demanding to know why you have to leave them to go to work. While transition moments (e.g.

The Promise and Peril of a High-Priced Sleep Trainer

The New Yorker · 22 min

Open Instagram and behold the perfect, zonked-out babies, lulled to sleep by methods designed by expensive coaches.

What Every Dad Should Keep in Mind About Parenting Humor

Fatherly · 5 min

Humor is a powerful tool in a parent's arsenal. But it's good to think about whether a dad joke is used to lighten the mood, or maintain distance.

My Introverted Teen Is Desperate to Be Popular

Slate · 12 min

Care and Feeding is Slate’s parenting advice column. Have a question for Care and Feeding? Submit it here or post it in the Slate Parenting Facebook group. I know this is going to sound like a non-problem at first, but there is a deeper issue that troubles me.

The Secret Recipe for All-Fun Parenting

The New York Times · 5 min

Frank Bruni will stop writing regular Opinion columns in late June, but his popular weekly newsletter will live on. To keep up with his political analysis, cultural commentary and personal reflections, sign up here. When she was a toddler, I showed my niece Leslie the Atlantic Ocean.

‘Peppa Pig, with better parenting’: the bounding success of canine cartoon Bluey

The Guardian · 5 min

Bluey is the best show on television, but nothing about its premise would suggest that this is the case.

Why Movies Love Kids’ Books

The New Yorker · 7 min

The milking of children’s literature is now a dairy industry. Movies, in particular, continue to pump away. You might think that every drop has been wrung from the classic texts, yet still, unceasingly, fresh adaptations emerge.

My Roommate Keeps Breaking My One Rule About My Kid

Slate · 15 min

Care and Feeding is Slate’s parenting advice column. Have a question for Care and Feeding? Submit it here or post it in the Slate Parenting Facebook group. My 13-year-old daughter went to live with her dad just before the pandemic.

Raising Kids to Love Exercise

The New York Times · 4 min

Body positive ways to encourage the joy of movement.

Greenpoint Playground Parents Rumble Over McGolrick Park’s Kiddie ‘Fight Club’

Curbed · 7 min

On a sweltering June day, a welter of yelps rose from the playground in the northeastern corner of Greenpoint’s leafy, tidy McGolrick Park. The playground had been lined with a sturdy foam in 2018 to soften the landings of children. But there were still injuries to be had.

My Husband Wants to Force Our Overscheduled Kid to Get a Job

Slate · 11 min

Care and Feeding is Slate’s parenting advice column. Have a question for Care and Feeding? Submit it here or post it in the Slate Parenting Facebook group.

entry.title: Why do we buy what we buy? (Pocket Explore Personal Finance)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Personal Finance

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

Why do we buy what we buy?

Vox · 14 min

A sociologist on why people buy too many things.

Why everything feels more expensive right now

Vox · 10 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Millennials’ Real Estate FOMO Goes Haywire

Bloomberg · 4 min

Here’s a word to add to your investing vocabulary: Dungers. The term for dilapidated, crumbling houses comes from New Zealand, which is in the grip of a striking property boom.

This couple retired at 38 in 1991 with $500,000 in savings. Here's how their investments have lasted over the years

CNBC · 1 min

Billy and Akaisha Kaderli feel like they have seen it all. The couple retired in 1991 at the age of 38 after saving $500,000.

Peter Thiel’s $5 Billion Roth IRA Tax Haven Is the Hottest New Investing Tip

VICE · 6 min

A ProPublica investigation exposed how billionaire Peter Thiel used a Roth IRA to dodge millions in taxes. To many in the finance world, it just revealed Thiel as an inspiration.

Real-estate investor Mike Bryant breaks down the strategy he used to acquire 10 properties 'without putting a nickel into' them — and shares why he recently decided to sell all but 4

Business Insider · 4 min

When Mike Bryant was in his early 50s in 2012, he started to think about ways he could further build his retirement portfolio. That's when he turned to real-estate investing. But it can be a tough market to break into, especially without large amounts of cash for a down payment.

Cracks in the Housing Market Are Starting to Show

Bloomberg · 4 min

Single-family housing in the U.S. has been exuberant, but it’s vulnerable and the bubble is starting to leak. Robust demand has come first and foremost from the massive monetary and fiscal stimulus that has pumped trillions of dollars directly into the pockets of consumers.

  • Coronavirus
  • Business

Here's what your budget should look like if you make $50,000 per year

CNBC · 1 min

Tracking your finances doesn't have to be complicated. A budget starts with a list of your income and your expenses. There are plenty of tools you can use to manage your money from there, but one of the most simple strategies is the 50-30-20 rule.

A new wave of buyers expected to hit B.C. real estate market

The Globe and Mail · 6 min

Throughout the pandemic, home sales soared, and in some markets, set record prices. Industry insiders say that postpandemic, the B.C. housing market is expected to boom again – driven by Canadians returning home and the federal government’s plan to bring in more than 1.

How to Invest in Stocks

The Motley Fool · 8 min

If you are ready to start investing in the stock market, but aren't sure of the first steps to take when investing in stocks, you’ve come to the right place. It might surprise you to learn that a $10,000 investment in the S&P 500 index 50 years ago would be worth nearly $1.2 million today.

I Lost My High-Paying Job During the Pandemic. Now I Have $40,000 in Credit Card Debt.

Slate · 9 min

Pay Dirt is Slate’s money advice column. Have a question? Send it to Athena and Elizabeth here. (It’s anonymous!) I had a lucrative job for two years leading up to the pandemic—about $120,000 a year—and got laid off right at the beginning of lockdowns.

Here's how to get $100,000 in annual tax-free income during retirement

CNBC · 6 min

It's a sure bet that no one — regardless of age — enjoys handing over any of their income to the IRS. In retirement, though, doing so can feel like even more of a sting.

Woman Checks Bank Account After Night Out, Discovers She's $49 Billion in Debt

Newsweek · 3 min

We've all been too afraid to check our bank account after a night out, over fears we spent too much. One woman decided to be brave and peek at her finances in the early hours of the morning after heading to a bar, only to find she was $49 billion in debt.

World’s Bubbliest Housing Markets Flash 2008 Style Warnings

Bloomberg · 2 min

Real estate prices around the world are flashing the kind of bubble warnings that haven’t been seen since the run up to the 2008 financial crisis, according to Bloomberg Economics.

Warren Buffett's Investing Strategy: An Inside Look

Investopedia · 3 min

A staunch believer in the value-based investing model, investment guru Warren Buffett has long held the belief that people should only buy stocks in companies that exhibit solid fundamentals, strong earnings power, and the potential for continued growth.

The secret truth of the student debt crisis

The Week · 8 min

The student debt crisis has gotten wide attention over the last several years. Democratic Sens.

2021 vs. 1992: I couldn’t afford my Toronto house if I had to buy in Canada’s current real estate market

The Globe and Mail · 3 min

Buying a home in the Toronto of 1992 was a bit of a stretch for twentysomething couples, but you got it done without much drama. That’s how I recall things when my wife and I bought our first house almost 30 years ago.

Billionaire Peter Thiel amasses $5bn tax-free nest egg in retirement account

The Guardian · 3 min

Billionaire Peter Thiel, one of the founders of PayPal, has used a retirement account designed to help ordinary Americans save for their golden years to amass a $5bn tax-free nest egg, according to records obtained by ProPublica.

Opinion: Your 401(k) fees could cost you half a million dollars in retirement

MarketWatch · 5 min

Ask anyone with a 401(k) plan at work what they pay in fees and the answers may surprise you: Most people think they pay nothing at all. Even those who know that’s impossible undershoot by a surprisingly large margin, guessing “about 1%” in fees.

Bitcoin crash opens door to a tax loophole for investors

CNBC · 3 min

Crypto investors may be shellshocked by a recent plunge in prices. But that sell-off has a silver lining: It opens the door to a money saving tax strategy. Popular cryptocurrencies like bitcoin and ethereum shed more than half their value in volatile trading over the past month or so.

The housing market is so hot buyers are paying $1 million over asking price

CNN · 6 min

What do homebuyers have to do to get a house in this cutthroat real estate market? Offer sellers a Caribbean vacation? Bid $1 million over the asking price? Pay a competing bidder hundreds of thousands of dollars to walk away?

Should you consider selling your home and renting in retirement?

The Globe and Mail · 4 min

When it comes to home ownership, we Canadians are a committed bunch. About two-thirds of us own our homes, making us among the world leaders in that category. We even have a burgeoning home-equity loan industry to help the home-rich but cash-poor stay in their houses after retiring.

entry.title: The Brontosaurus Is Back (Pocket Explore Science)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Science

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

The Brontosaurus Is Back

Scientific American · 3 min

Decades after scientists decided that the famed dinosaur never actually existed, research says the opposite.

The Life and Suspicious Death of Cachou the Bear

Bloomberg · 17 min

Why Are We Obsessed With Weather?

The Atlantic · 4 min

‘Unrecognizable.’ Lake Mead, a lifeline for water in Los Angeles and the West, tips toward crisis

Los Angeles Times · 9 min

Unraveling the Enigma of Reason

Scott Young · 10 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

Earth Has a 27.5-Million-Year 'Heartbeat', But We Don't Know What Causes It

ScienceAlert · 3 min

In the last 260 million years, dinosaurs came and went, Pangea split into the continents and islands we see today, and humans have quickly and irreversibly changed the world we live in. But through all of that, it seems Earth has been keeping time.

Warp drives: Physicists give chances of faster-than-light space travel a boost

The Conversation · 5 min

The closest star to Earth is Proxima Centauri. It is about 4.25 light-years away, or about 25 trillion miles (40 trillion km). The fastest ever spacecraft, the now- in-space Parker Solar Probe will reach a top speed of 450,000 mph.

Some Scientists Believe the Universe Is Conscious

Popular Mechanics · 5 min

Buckle in, because things are about to get weird.

How Maxwell’s Demon Continues to Startle Scientists

Quanta Magazine · 5 min

The thorny thought experiment has been turned into a real experiment — one that physicists use to probe the physics of information.

The 5 mass extinction events that shaped the history of Earth — and the 6th that's happening now

Live Science · 11 min

The death of the dinosaurs was just one of five global events that saw millions of species wiped out. How do these events happen? And how can we stop it happening again?

Discover More Topics

  • Coronavirus
  • Business
  • Career
  • Education
  • Entertainment
  • Food
  • Gaming
  • Health & Fitness
  • Parenting
  • Personal Finance
  • Politics
  • Science
  • Self Improvement
  • Sports
  • Technology
  • Travel

10 mind-boggling things you should know about quantum physics

Space.com · 7 min

The quantum world has a lot in common with shoes. You can’t just go to a shop and pick out sneakers that are an exact match for your feet. Instead, you’re forced to choose between pairs that come in predetermined sizes. The subatomic world is similar.

NASA’s bold bet on Starship for the Moon may change spaceflight forever

Ars Technica · 16 min

"It is transformational to degrees no one today can understand."

Is human consciousness creating reality?

Big Think · 4 min

A new study claims networks of observers are responsible for determining physical reality.The scientists propose that observers generate the structures of time and space.The paper could help yield insights into the God Equation, which attempts to unify quantum mechanics and general relativity.

Secrets of a tree whisperer: ‘They get along, they listen – they’re attuned’

The Guardian · 7 min

Suzanne Simard revolutionised the way we think about plants and fungi with the discovery of the woodwide web. The ecologist’s new book shares the wisdom of a life of listening to the forest.

‘It Seems That I Know How the Universe Originated’

The Atlantic · 22 min

The theoretical physicist Andrei Linde may have the world’s most expansive conception of what infinity looks like.

Was Einstein wrong? Why some astrophysicists are questioning the theory of space-time

Space.com · 8 min

As in history, revolutions are the lifeblood of science. Bubbling undercurrents of disquiet boil over until a new regime emerges to seize power. Then everyone's attention turns to toppling their new ruler. The king is dead, long live the king.

AI Designs Quantum Physics Experiments Beyond What Any Human Has Conceived

Scientific American · 9 min

Quantum physicist Mario Krenn remembers sitting in a café in Vienna in early 2016, poring over computer printouts, trying to make sense of what MELVIN had found. MELVIN was a machine-learning algorithm Krenn had built, a kind of artificial intelligence.

Physicists Identify the Engine Powering Black Hole Energy Beams

Quanta Magazine · 10 min

Supermassive black holes emit jets of white-hot plasma that stretch thousands of light-years across the cosmos. For the first time, researchers have identified what’s creating these jets.

A Mysterious Crater’s Age May Add Clues to the Dinosaur Extinction

The New York Times · 4 min

Boltysh crater in Ukraine formed around the same time as the Chicxulub event, raising questions about its role in this tumultuous era. Some 65 million years ago, a rock from outer space slammed into Earth, wreaking havoc on life in its wake and leaving a large crater on our planet’s surface.

The mystery of how big our Universe really is

BBC · 9 min

Let's start by saying the Universe is big. When we look in any direction, the furthest visible regions of the Universe are estimated to be around 46 billion light years away. That's a diameter of 540 sextillion (or 54 followed by 22 zeros) miles.

Human Evolution Led to an Extreme Thirst for Water

Scientific American · 12 min

We are more dependent on water than many other mammals and have developed a host of clever strategies for obtaining it.

Why Does the Universe Exist? Some Perspectives from Our Physics Project—Stephen Wolfram Writings

writings.stephenwolfram.com · 40 min

What Is Formal, and What Is Actualized? Why does the universe exist? Why is there something rather than nothing? These are old and fundamental questions that one might think would be firmly outside the realm of science.

What Made Early Humans Smart

Nautilus · 15 min

Walking upright made our ancestors easy prey. It also made them get smart.

The Unified Universe

Aeon · 15 min

Physics displays an uncanny alignment at its very deepest levels. Is a grand theory of everything finally within reach?

Wormhole Tunnels in Spacetime May Be Possible, New Research Suggests

Scientific American · 4 min

In the early days of research on black holes, before they even had that name, physicists did not yet know if these bizarre objects existed in the real world. They might have been a quirk of the complicated math used in the then still young general theory of relativity, which describes gravity.

entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Self Improvement

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

Why disagreement is vital to advancing human understanding

Aeon · 15 min

Disagreements can be unpleasant, even offensive, but they are vital to human reason. Without them we remain in the dark.

You Can Unshrink Your Shrunken Clothes

Lifehacker · 3 min

There Are Three Sides to Every Argument

TED Ideas · 10 min

How to Become a Master at Talking to Strangers

Entrepreneur · 19 min

How to Gracefully Turn Down Plans You Can’t Afford

The Cut · 7 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

The Most Effective Way to Thank Your Significant Other

The Atlantic · 3 min

One fact of long-term relationships is that humans often take their partner for granted. Think of gratitude as a buffer against that. It’s so simple that it can be easy to overlook: In the commotion of daily life, people forget to thank their partner for the myriad things they do.

5 Habits That Made Me a Millionaire by 25

Entrepreneur · 5 min

You don't need superpowers to become a millionaire. Believe me, I became one by the age of 25, and I started from very humble beginnings. When I was a teenager, I began to study rich people: their behavior and what made them more successful than other people.

170 Hypothetical Questions That'll Give Your Brain a Workout

parade.com · 15 min

Chatting can quickly get boring when you stick to small talk.

Avoid these 5 phrases that make you sound passive aggressive—here's how successful people communicate

CNBC · 4 min

Today, we live in a world where business, degrees and even entire relationships are conducted behind a screen.

6 Brain Damaging Habits You May Want to Quit

Medium · 9 min

86 billion. That’s the number of cells your brain has. Without a doubt, the gooey mass between your ears is controlling your body like nothing else. It only makes sense to spend most of our time taking care of it. But we don’t. In fact, most don’t even think the brain needs care.

Aging is inevitable, so why not do it joyfully? Here’s how

TED · 14 min

“Aging gracefully” entails walking a tightrope between a youth-obsessed society, which tells us that our value declines as we age, and a culture that says nothing is as uncool as desperation, the fervent desire for something we can’t have.

7 Ways to Reset Your Relationship

The New York Times · 7 min

Experts say couples can emerge from the pandemic stronger than ever by learning from the past and looking toward the future.

The Revival of Stoicism

VICE · 26 min

Everyone from Silicon Valley billionaires to self-help enthusiasts is repurposing Stoicism for our modern age, with results that are good, bad, and highly indifferent.

The Key to Find Time for Learning

scotthyoung.com · 5 min

At the end of the week, there may only be few hours to learn new things. How do you fit it in?

3 Daily Habits That Make Jeff Bezos More Productive Than You

Entrepreneur · 4 min

Every entrepreneur gets a limited amount of time to accomplish their life and business goals, experience fun moments and make an impact. They get a finite window to be a leader in business.

3 healthier ways to cope with criticism, disappointment and defeat

TED · 8 min

One of the most fundamental human needs is to feel like things are basically OK — that we’re not failures, that the world isn’t a horrible place, and that whatever life throws at us, we’ll be able to handle it.

Why we remember more by reading – especially print – than from audio or video

The Conversation · 4 min

The reasons relate to a variety of factors, including diminished concentration, an entertainment mindset and a tendency to multitask while consuming digital content.

‘Follow Your Passion’ Is The Worst Career Advice—Here’s Why

Forbes · 3 min

It’s a cliché as old as time: When it comes to your career, people often say to “follow your passion.” While this slogan is splashed across self-help books, heard in graduation speeches and even touted by career coaches, it may not be very sound advice.

The Clock-Out Cure

The Cut · 6 min

For those who can afford it, quitting has become the ultimate form of self-care.

How to Make Your Small Talk Big

The New York Times · 8 min

We are all relearning how to talk to one another, and this isn’t just because of the pandemic.

Bad at public speaking? Use this mental trick that takes just 15 minutes, says speech expert

CNBC · 4 min

Speech anxiety is one of the most common social fears, affecting 15% to 30% of the general population. After a difficult speech or two, most of us assume that we're just shy, then hope that we'll never be forced to speak in public again.

Tough compassion — here’s what it is and why you need to practice it

TED · 8 min

Tough compassion is gaining traction because the rosy version is proving so unequal to the present moment.

Authenticity is a sham

Aeon · 15 min

From monks to existentialists and hipsters, the search for a true self has been a centuries-long project. Should we give it up?

A psychologist says parents of 'exceptionally resilient and successful' kids always do these 7 things: 'Yes, some are a little intense'

CNBC · 5 min

Humans are not all equal in every way. There are a few individuals who have achieved an unparalleled mastery in their field — and they are what I call the exceptionals. Put another way, they are the 1% of the 1% of the world's most successful people.

Want to build someone’s confidence? Ask for their advice

TED · 8 min

Too often, we assume the obstacle to change in others is ignorance, so we offer advice. But what if the problem is a lack of confidence?

entry.content:

Technology

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

The Washington Post · 10 min

This is the decade that computers became the boss of you.

Luxury Surveillance

reallifemag.com · 10 min

Failure to Launch: Why Jetpacks Never Took Off

Sports Illustrated · 19 min

How Vlogging Is Empowering a New Generation of Stutterers

catapult.co · 8 min

The Computer Maverick Who Modeled the Evolution of Life

Nautilus · 12 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

12 hidden Pixel phone superpowers

Computerworld · 13 min

One of the best parts of using a Pixel is the way tasty little specks of Google intelligence get sprinkled all throughout the experience.

How to poison the data that Big Tech uses to surveil you

MIT Technology Review · 5 min

Algorithms are meaningless without good data. The public can exploit that to demand change. Every day, your life leaves a trail of digital breadcrumbs that tech giants use to track you. You send an email, order some food, stream a show.

‘I was addicted to the high’: I became an influencer as a joke – then it nearly broke me

The Guardian · 16 min

Comedian Bella Younger thought wellness Instagrammers were ripe for parody. Soon she was drawn in herself. Could Deliciously Stella find her way back to reality?

The Best Tech and Apps for Your Home Office

The New York Times · 31 min

We updated the thumb drive, lightning cable, Qi wireless charger, Bluetooth headset, and budgeting sections to reflect the new picks in those guides. You don’t need the thinnest, lightest, or most elegantly designed items for your home office.

Nikola Tesla: 5G Network Could Realize His Dream of Wireless Electricity

singularityhub.com · 4 min

At the height of his career, the pioneering electrical engineer Nikola Tesla became obsessed with an idea.

  • Coronavirus
  • Business

Hacking bitcoin wallets with quantum computers could happen – but cryptographers are racing to build a workaround

CNBC · 4 min

Stefan Thomas really could have used a quantum computer this year. The German-born programmer and crypto trader forgot the password to unlock his digital wallet, which contains 7,002 bitcoin, now worth $265 million.

Why You Should Switch From Android Messages Given Security Concerns

Forbes · 5 min

Somewhat ironically, , Google seems yet again to have slipped by unnoticed. Now, hundreds of millions of Android users need to decide who they trust with their data, given recent harvesting revelations. Android Messages is trying to fix the major security holes in its architecture.

The Best Online Cloud Backup Service

The New York Times · 33 min

Starting August 16, Backblaze is raising its price to $70 a year. The increase is moderate enough we still think Backblaze is a good option. Every cloud backup service we tested is a pain to use for one reason or another, but we still recommend using one.

How Much Energy Does Bitcoin Actually Consume?

Harvard Business Review · 9 min

Today, Bitcoin consumes as much energy as a small country. This certainly sounds alarming — but the reality is a little more complicated.

A Global Smart-City Competition Highlights China’s Rise in AI

WIRED · 5 min

Chinese entrants swept all five categories, featuring technologies to improve civic life. But the advances could also be tools for surveillance.

Tech vs. Journalism

New York Magazine · 25 min

Inside the nasty battle between Silicon Valley and the reporters who write about it.

The Day Facebook Ruined the Internet

The New York Times · 2 min

Mr. Hurwitz-Goodman is a filmmaker based in Los Angeles. Your uncle caught a flounder this afternoon. President Biden said something about the Middle East. It’s your boss’s birthday.

T-Mobile Home Internet Review: A Wireless Carrier Might Be Your Next Internet Service Provider

Newsweek · 6 min

If you live in the U.S., there's a good chance you connect to the internet in your home using a wired modem. That number is a majority 63 percent, according to a Statista Global Consumer Survey conducted in 2020 in the United States.

These creepy fake humans herald a new age in AI

MIT Technology Review · 7 min

Need more data for deep learning? Synthetic data companies will make it for you.

China's tech workers pushed to limits by surveillance software

The Nikkei · 16 min

HONG KONG -- Andy Wang, an IT engineer at a Shanghai-based gaming company, occasionally felt a pang of guilt about his job. Most of his hours were spent on a piece of surveillance software called DiSanZhiYan, or "Third Eye.

Can facial analysis technology create a child-safe internet?

The Guardian · 9 min

Suppose you pulled out your phone this morning to post a pic to your favourite social network – let’s call it Twinstabooktok – and were asked for a selfie before you could log on.

Yahoo, the Destroyer

The Atlantic · 8 min

Yahoo Answers is not what most people would call a good source of information.

Remote work made digital nomads possible. The pandemic made them essential

Fast Company · 14 min

Special visas. Free Vaccines. Tax breaks. Countries around the world are courting a new class of human capital that wants to mix travel and work forever.

Collective data rights can stop big tech from obliterating privacy

MIT Technology Review · 10 min

Every person engaged with the networked world constantly creates rivers of data. We do this in ways we are aware of, and ways that we aren’t. Corporations are eager to take advantage.

Welcome to TechScape: will AI make centaurs of us all?

The Guardian · 11 min

Hello and welcome to the debut issue of TechScape, the Guardian’s newsletter on all things tech, and sometimes things not-tech if they’re interesting enough.

entry.title: 6 U.S. Islands Where You Can’t Help but Slow Down (Pocket Explore Travel)
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Travel

Curated by our editorsStories to fuel your mind

6 U.S. Islands Where You Can’t Help but Slow Down

Afar · 3 min

Whether you’re strolling the coast of an Atlantic island or savoring the sunset on Hawaii’s low-key paradise, you’ll be surprised at how quickly time becomes irrelevant.

The Best Campground in Every State

Outside Magazine · 25 min

How Some People Can End Up Living at Airports for Months – Even Years – at a Time

The Conversation · 5 min

Nobody Knows What Lies Beneath New York City

Bloomberg Businessweek · 17 min

Popular with Pocket readersStories from across the web

America's Most Scenic Road Trips

Travel + Leisure · 10 min

These are 23 of the best road trips in the U.S.A. Editor's Note: Those who choose to travel are strongly encouraged to check local government restrictions, rules, and safety measures related to COVID-19 and take personal comfort levels and health conditions into consideration before departure.

United Airlines Wants to Bring Back Supersonic Air Travel

The New York Times · 4 min

The airline, which plans to buy planes from Boom Supersonic, a start-up, could become the first to offer ultrafast commercial flights since the Concorde stopped flying in 2003.

Airbnb Is Spending Millions of Dollars to Make Nightmares Go Away

Bloomberg · 23 min

When things go horribly wrong during a stay, the company’s secretive safety team jumps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families—and prevent PR disasters.

You can book an around-the-world award ticket for just 75,000 miles — here’s how

The Points Guy · 16 min

With international travel making a return this summer, many of you are itching to get back out there and see the world. Whether it’s for international first class or a quick hop around the U.S., now is a good time to put your hard-earning airline miles to use.

France is banning any short flight that can be replaced by a train trip

Fast Company · 2 min

If you can get there within 180 minutes on the train, you won’t be able to fly. 1 minute ReadIt takes around two hours to take a train from Paris to the city of Lyon.

  • Coronavirus
  • Business

The Best Gear for Travel

The New York Times · 69 min

Eagle Creek is shutting down. So far we aren't sure how long our picks will remain in stock. If you can pick them up the Eagle Creek Pack-It Original Cube Set and Eagle Creek Pack-It Specter Tech Cube Set remain our favorite packing cubes. Eagle Creek is shutting down.

Two strangers, a canceled flight and an unexpected road trip

CNN

Jackie Battagello and David Rosenfeld were total strangers whose paths unexpectedly crossed when their flight was canceled. Joining forces, they hitched a ride with strangers to the next airport. What happened next surprised them both.

A great American road trip through Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wyoming

The Points Guy · 12 min

Talk about a great American road trip. I’ve been living at my father’s ranch in rural Montana ever since the COVID-19 pandemic shut down our New York City offices in March 2020.

How to Pack a Backpack for Backpacking

The Art of Manliness · 4 min

Remember to not only pack the heavier items near the top, but close to your back and in-between your shoulder blades.

The 11 best luggage brands of 2021 whether you're planning a road trip or a far-flung vacation

Business Insider · 8 min

Chances are you've seen this buzzy brand popular with millennials pop up on your Instagram at one point or another. Away has multiple options for roller luggage, including hard-sided, expandable, and aluminum.

New Zealand to spend millions weaning holiday towns off international tourism

The Guardian · 3 min

The days of allowing tourist hordes to some of New Zealand’s best-known natural attractions are over, the government has signalled, as it unveiled new plans to protect the environment and reconsider the role of tourism in its economy.

Claiming the Summit Without Reaching the Top

The New York Times · 14 min

Only 44 people have reached the summit of all 14 of the world’s 8,000-meter peaks, according to the people who chronicle such things.

Inside the Thrilling, Slightly Terrifying World of Austrian Hut-to-Hut Hiking

afar.com · 16 min

In Austria, where the Alps cover 62 percent of the country, hiking is just a part of regular life. An intrepid American writer laces up his boots.

Who Gets to Travel to “Find Themselves”?

catapult.co · 12 min

The spirit of manifest destiny has been rebranded into the travelogue.In this age of going nowhere, I’ve been thinking about the times I could not sit still. My life has been defined by the arc of a plane.

10 of the coolest holiday rentals in Scotland

The Guardian · 7 min

Two converted horseboxes, Thistle and Juniper, have been added to the collection of self-catering and glamping accommodation at the Alexander House estate in Perthshire.

How to Plan a D.I.Y. Alaska Trip

The New York Times · 9 min

In a state the size of Texas, California and Montana combined, planning an affordable itinerary can be a challenge, especially with this summer’s lack of cheap cruises.

The medieval nuns’ guide to virtual travel

The Economist · 4 min

On a cold January morning in 1417, Sister Truyde Schutten asked a fellow nun from her convent in the Netherlands to join her on a pilgrimage to Rome. If they left promptly, Truyde said, they could make it there for the feast day of St Agnes, the patron saint of virgins, on January 21st.

The Pandemic Has Undone South Africa’s National Parks

The Atlantic · 18 min

Without tourism, the funding that sustains some of the world’s most treasured wildlife has atrophied.

The Sentiero dei Parchi: A new hiking trail uniting Italy

BBC · 9 min

On a recent evening, Elia Origoni stood at Sardinia’s south-eastern tip, watching the azure sky darken until it merged with the sea, and contemplating the most daunting leg of his ambitious trip.

Plan For Your Great National Park Trip

NPR · 3 min

With the COVID-19 pandemic apparently coming to a close, many Americans are preparing for a no-holds-barred summer filled with many activities that the coronavirus has outlawed for more than a year. Here are some tips from the National Park Service to help visitors make the most their trip.
